Abstract.Heading: Abstract
Abstract.Para:
The plasmon resonance of periodic and random arrays of Au-nanodiscs and nano-squares was investigated experimentally and numerically. By randomization, plasmon resonance spectra become broadened, however, the electro-magnetic field enhancement is augmented by a factor of 10–10
$$^2$$
2
times at some specific wavelength as shown by the finite-element time-domain calculations. The spatial localization takes place at a fewer hot-spots. The randomized structures are promising for the applications in opto-electronics, sensing and light harvesting.

Section1.Heading: Introduction
Section1.Para: The localized surface plasmon resonances (LSPRs) are generated by nanostructures of noble metals such as gold, silver and copper, which are attractive and promising materials in the field of opto-electronics, photochemistry, and solar energy applications. Also, it is an important tool for the detection of small number of molecules with high sensitivity, high selectivity using surface enhanced Raman scattering (SERS) and surface enhanced infrared absorption (SEIRA) spectroscopic measurements [1–7]. Recently configuration of a nanopattern has been paid much of attention for controlling the wide-angle light-plasmon coupling [8–15]. In the case of plasmon resonance, one nanostructure itself play as the resonator to the light and is coupled to other resonators in close vicinity. Configuration of the pattern of nanoparticles becomes important for propagation scattering and active emission (spacer) similarly to the photonic crystals and is currently actively researched. Apparently, random patterns of nanoparticles are increasing the efficiency of organic solar cells [16].

Periodic arrays of nanostructures which are widely produced by top-down nanotechnology techniques have the Bragg diffraction dominant effects and scatters light into diffraction modes, they appear as resonant scattering bands in excitation. The diffracted light departs from surface and is lost for light harvesting. However, when periodicity of pattern is broken by randomization, spectroscopic properties and electro-magnetic (EM) field enhancement are modified favorably for light harvesting. The benefit of studying the (quasi)-random structure is promising for cost reduction of fabrication. The quality of tools used in nanofabrication is developing rapidly with advances in the accuracy down to the nanometer-sized gap, high through-put, high reproductivity at lower electron beam acceleration voltages and less damage to the substrate [17]. The (quasi-) random of nanoparticles pattern can be created not only by top-down methods but also by bottom-up approach including the chemical synthesis. Therefore, for the large area applications (such as white light applications like LEDs, solar cells, photo catalysis and so on) better understanding of the plasmon resonance and EM-field enhancement is required.

In this study, we demonstrate how randomization affects the optical extinction spectra of well-defined arrays of gold nanodiscs and square as disorder is gradually increased. The experimental results are analyzed numerically and show significant EM-field enhancement favorable for the spectrally broad light enhancement.

Section1.Heading: Experiments
Section1.Para:
Arrays of nanodiscs were fabricated by top-down approach using electron beam (EB) lithography and lift-off technique as reported earlier [9, 12, 18]. EB resist (ZEP-520A ZEON Co.) was coated on the glass substrate by spin coating (3,000 rpm for 2 min). Top of resist was covered with charge dissipating agent (ESPACER, Showa Denko Co.). Patterns of gold nanoparticles are CAD generated by the random-walk method starting from a perfectly periodic pattern, with increasing the mean free length of random walking. After EB drawing process and development, 2 nm of Cr (as the adhesion layer) and 25 nm of Au have been coated with thermal evaporation. Then, EB resist with residual metal over-coating was removed by organic solvent; the obtained gold nanoparticles were used for experiments. As randomization is increased, the plasmon resonance slightly blue-shifts, decreasing the extinction value, and broadens the spectral width (see Fig. 3b). As shown in the optical microscopy image, the internal diffraction condition is removed by the randomization process. This tendency becomes stronger when using thicker nanodiscs of 65-nm thickness. Part of the scattered light leaves the surface, and part experiences total internal reflection at large angles and is bound to the surface. The surface-bound wave is scattered by the nanoparticles and its effects on extinction and enhancement are analyzed in the next Sect. 3.2.

Section2.Heading: FDTD analysis of periodic and random pattern
Section2.Para:
In order to study the response of the ordered and disordered patterns, we designed and simulated a layout based of the
$$\varLambda = 600$$
Λ = 600
nm period case, as it has better response to the short-wavelength range, as visible in Fig. 3. To better exploit the calculation resources available, we first did a preliminary study on smaller-size square particles better suited for the structured mesh of the finite-element time-domain (FDTD) method. This was acceptable for the study, as the long-wavelength resonance will mostly experience a shift, while short-wavelength response is dominated by the material characteristics. The comparison stands as the size of the particles is unchanged while the layout is randomized.

The space left between the TFSF boundary and the domain boundary is needed to avoid spurious coupling and resonances between the discontinuities introduced by these two boundaries. In the case of the random layouts, the layout is slightly adjusted to avoid the blocks crossing the non-physical boundary of the TFSF source, though this does not influence the response significantly because of the averaging effect of having a large number of blocks in the domain.

The central part is illuminated with a bandwidth between 400 and 1,400 nm wavelength, measuring absorption, scattering, and extinction cross sections and the E-field intensity enhancement normalized to source intensity. With increasing randomization, the cross-section spectra broaden with the peaks blue-shift. This feature reprodices well the experimental results of transmission measurements shown in Fig. 2. In addition, in the case of random patterns, absorption cross section

(which gives account of the loss in the metal) was reduced in the random pattern when in the maximum extinction condition. This increases the scattering efficiency composed to the periodic pattern, albeit with lower extinction. In the case of the random structure, each nanodisc has a slightly different resonance wavelength because of different long-range interaction, thus the randomly scattered light is spread over a wider range of wavelengths. Spectrally broader plasmon resonances like this are favorable in practical light harvesting applications.

we analyzed the maximum field enhancement value over all the calculation area that is flush with the top of the nano-blocks, plotted against the irradiation light wavelength. The results are shown in Fig. 5.

In the case of periodic allay (Fig. 5a), the maximum intensity spectra have a profile similar to the cross sections. Therefore, the profile broadens around 1,000 nm wavelength to a maximum intensity of 500 times the source. Interestingly, around 660 nm we observe a narrow and strong peak (where normalized intensity reaches 1,700). The same feature can be seen in the absorption cross section and we can see a small distortion in the scattering and extinction cross section in Fig. 4a. This narrow and strong enhancement of the EM field is due to a Fano-like resonance coupling between plasmon resonance and diffraction [18–22]. As we previously reported, EM-field enhancement strongly depends on the plasmon resonance wavelength and its periodicity [9]. It is important to control the coupling of plasmon resonance and diffraction for efficient EM-field enhancement. However, in the random pattern, EM enhancement features become quite different from the periodic pattern. Maximum enhancement reaches 7,000, which is 14 times as large as periodic pattern at plasmon peak wavelength. Its profile is also related to the plasmon resonance, however it is not smooth and has many peaks. Even around 1,300 nm wavelength, which has weaker extinction than peak wavelength, it shows 1,000 times enhancement (two times higher than the periodic pattern).

This strong enhancement would appear as long as the plasmon resonance exists. The features of random array structures (broadband resonance and low extinction loss with strong enhancement) can be especially promising as materials for white-voltaic devices and solar cells, photo-detectors, and photochemical processes like photo catalysts. Also, the broad band resonance and narrow, strong enhancement features appearing in Fig. 5 are significant in that there will contribute to sensitivity in SERS and SEIRA applications. As already discussed widely in literature, the SERS intensity depends on the EM-field enhancement both at excitation and scattering wavelength. In case of the plasmon resonance of aperiodic structure, it is difficult to tune both excitation and Raman scattering to the maximum EM enhancement wavelength. However, in the random substrate, we have a strong wide-band enhancement which can cover a wide range of SERS signals. We also have the possibility to enhance a specific signal, which can increase specific molecular selectivity in SERS measurements [23].

Section1.Heading: Conclusions
Section1.Para:
In this study, we have demonstrated the effect of periodic and random particle patterns on the plasmonic resonance. An increase of extinction and a broader plasmon resonance occur with increasing the randomness in case of nanodiscs as can be visualized by dark-field. FDTD calculations show an augmentation of the enhancement by more than two order of magnitude for the random configuration of nano-squares with spectral broadening and field enhancement effects. Broad band and narrow peak appearance in the enhancement profile is shown by FDTD calculations. This unique features have potential to be applied to both the white light harvesting and for SERS/SEIRA sensing. Recently, the enhancement of SERS intensity by an order of magnitude as compared to that on periodic patterns [24] is demonstrated on laser-ablated ripples [25]. The randomness of the hot-spots on scale of tens-of-nanometers is attributed for this effect and SERS sensitivity can be increased to detect gaseous precursors of explosives [26]. This is achieved without compromise of spatial uniformity over sensing surface since SERS intensity is integrated over hot-spots occurring within 2- to 5-
$$\upmu $$
μ
m-diameter laser focus of the SERS readout.
